summary: This document outlines a planned series of interviews by investigators regarding the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 9-10, 2019. It focuses on staff failures, security protocols, cellmate requirements, and the institutional count process. The document is an internal planning memo for conducting interviews with Bureau of Prisons staff.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the investigation. The document examines the security and procedural failures related to his custody and death.

persons.name: Thomas
persons.context: Listed as working in R&D and on the 10 pm institutional out count on August 9, 2019. He is a subject of the investigation regarding notification procedures.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A staff member who, along with Thomas, is questioned about what actions they should have taken regarding Epstein's custody. He was on sick leave from 4 pm to 10 pm on August 9, 2019.

persons.name: C. Legrand
persons.context: Worked in control and R&D during the morning watch on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: Had discussions regarding Epstein and his cellmate requirement. Also received an email requesting information on the August 9 and 10 count issue.

persons.name: Regional Director
persons.context: Sent an email to a staff member asking what happened with the institutional count related to Epstein's death.

connections.description: Noel was a CO who was on email regarding Epstein's cellmate requirement and was on sick leave during the time of Epstein's death.
Thomas was a CO working in R&D and was involved in the institutional count process on the day of Epstein's death.
The Warden was involved in discussions and received communications regarding Epstein's specific custody requirements and the incident.
Both were COs whose actions and knowledge regarding Epstein's custody are under joint investigation.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The document investigates the procedural and security failures surrounding this event.

events.title: Institutional Count Failure
events.description: The 4 pm institutional count in the SHU was not properly conducted or signed off on by the required Lieutenants (Ops LT or Act LT), with signatures missing from the count slip.

events.title: Interview at FCI Danbury
events.description: Planned interview regarding the Activities Lieutenant's role and presence during the 4 pm count in the SHU on August 9, 2019, and knowledge of Epstein's cellmate requirement.

events.title: Interview at MCC (R&D Staff)
events.description: Planned interview with Receiving and Discharge (R&D) staff who would have been first notified about Epstein not returning to his cell and their notification procedures.

events.title: Interview at MCC (Ops LT)
events.description: Planned interview with the Operations Lieutenant who was the SHU Officer-in-Charge (OIC) on August 9, focusing on count procedures and notifications about Epstein.

events.title: Interview at NYFO (Epstein's Lawyers)
events.description: Planned interview, possibly with a staff member who overheard an Epstein call, and with Epstein's lawyers to determine his state of mind on August 9, 2019.

keyFacts: Investigators were examining significant procedural failures, including missing signatures on the 4 pm institutional count slip on August 9, 2019, the day Epstein died.

There were posted notices in the SHU, on Epstein's cell door and the OIC desk, stating that Epstein required a cellmate, indicating special custody protocols were in place but potentially not followed.
The SHU video system was reported to be down, and there were questions about whether SHU COs were conducting required rounds and counts.

The Receiving and Discharge (R&D) unit, not other staff, was responsible for being notified by courts or marshals about inmate movements and making proper notifications to the case manager coordinator.
Multiple staff members, including an Ops LT and an Act LT, were under scrutiny for not being present or fulfilling their duties during the critical count time when Epstein was unaccounted for.
